title: About
text: Zoey Schultz is a senior Data Science student at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln.

title: Why the Olympic Format Failed the World’s Best Climber
text:
Code
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  echo = TRUE,
  message = FALSE,
  warning = FALSE,
  results = 'hide'
)

suppressPackageStartupMessages({
  library(ggplot2)
  library(dplyr)
  library(readr)
  library(tidyr)
  library(lubridate)
  library(tibble)
  library(gt)
})
Adam Ondra is widely considered the best climber in the world — but how does his performance actually compare in competitions and on real rock?
Let’s look at some data from his IFSC results and outdoor ascents to explore his strengths, tradeoffs, and one surprising weakness that cost him at the Olympics.
Code
rankings <- read_csv("data/adam_master_rankings.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

filtered <- rankings |>
  filter(Discipline %in% c("lead", "boulder"),
         Date >= 2010, Date <= 2024)

avg_rankings <- filtered |>
  group_by(Date, Discipline) |>
  summarise(AverageRank = mean(Rank, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

chart1 <- ggplot(avg_rankings, aes(x = Date, y = AverageRank, color = Discipline)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(linewidth = 3) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("lead" = "#377eb8", "boulder" = "#e41a1c")) +
  labs(
    title = "Ondra Ruled IFSC Lead from 2013–2017",
    subtitle = "His rankings stayed dominant in lead until 2021, when results became inconsistent.",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average IFSC Rank (Lower is Better)",
    color = "Discipline"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "black"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
  )

ggsave("images/chart1.png", chart1, width = 8, height = 5)
Source: IFSC Rankings | By Zoey Schultz
Let’s start with competition. Adam Ondra has competed in IFSC events since his teens, and for a while, he dominated. This chart shows his average IFSC rankings from 2010 to 2024 in two disciplines: lead and boulder.
His golden era came between 2013 and 2017. During those years, Ondra was a near-permanent fixture on the podium in lead climbing and consistently ranked in the top 5. His bouldering rankings were slightly more volatile — still strong, but not at the same level as his lead performances.
Things start to shift around 2020–2021, coinciding with the Tokyo Olympics. That dip isn’t just a blip — it reflects a broader change in his climbing focus and possibly the rise of a younger generation of climbers who specialize in indoor formats.
Code
ascents <- read_csv("data/adam_all_ascents.csv", show_col_types = FALSE) |>
  select(-starts_with("..."))

ascents <- ascents |>
  filter(Grade %in% c("9a", "9a+", "9b", "9b+", "9c")) |>
  mutate(
    Date = suppressWarnings(dmy(Date)),
    Year = year(Date)
  ) |>
  filter(!is.na(Date))

sends_per_year <- ascents |>
  group_by(Year) |>
  summarise(HardSends = n(), .groups = "drop")

avg_ifsc_rank <- filtered |>
  group_by(Date) |>
  summarise(AvgRank = mean(Rank, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |>
  rename(Year = Date)

combined <- inner_join(sends_per_year, avg_ifsc_rank, by = "Year")

chart2 <- suppressMessages(
  ggplot(combined, aes(x = HardSends, y = AvgRank)) +
    geom_point(size = 4, color = "#377eb8") +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
    scale_y_reverse() +
    labs(
      title = "More Sends, Fewer Medals: Outdoor Focus Hurt Ondra's Rankings",
      subtitle = "Years with more 9a+ outdoor climbs saw worse IFSC results.",
      x = "Number of 9a+ Outdoor Sends",
      y = "Average IFSC Ranking (Lower is Better)"
    ) +
    theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
    theme(
      plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
      axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
      axis.text = element_text(color = "black"),
      panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
      panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
    )
)

ggsave("images/chart2.png", chart2, width = 8, height = 5)
Source: IFSC Rankings & Climbing History | By Zoey Schultz
This chart explores the tradeoff between Adam Ondra’s outdoor pursuits and his competitive performance. Specifically, it compares the number of 9a or harder routes he sent outdoors each year with his average IFSC ranking that same year.
There’s a clear pattern: when Ondra sends more hard outdoor routes, his IFSC ranking tends to suffer. This isn’t surprising — training for the World Cup circuit is incredibly specific, and time spent on real rock is time not spent in plastic bouldering gyms or lead training facilities.
The data suggests a strong inverse relationship between his outdoor activity and indoor performance. That may sound like a bad thing, but it also illustrates something important: Ondra wasn’t trying to win every competition. He prioritized a broader legacy — one that includes the world’s hardest outdoor climbs.
Code
climbers <- tibble::tibble(
  Climber = c("Adam Ondra", "Jakob Schubert", "Stefano Ghisolfi", "Tomoa Narasaki", "Sean Bailey"),
  HardestGrade = c("9c", "9b+", "9b+", "9a+", "9b"),
  Avg_IFSC_Rank = c(5.2, 6.1, 8.3, 7.5, 9.2),
  Medals = c(38, 31, 19, 17, 10),
  Highlight = c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE)
)

grade_map <- c("9a" = 28, "9a+" = 29, "9b" = 30, "9b+" = 31, "9c" = 32, "9c+" = 33)
climbers$GradeNumeric <- grade_map[climbers$HardestGrade]

chart3 <- ggplot(climbers, aes(x = GradeNumeric, y = Avg_IFSC_Rank, size = Medals, label = Climber)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Highlight), alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(vjust = 1.3, size = 4, fontface = ifelse(climbers$Climber == "Adam Ondra", "bold", "plain")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("TRUE" = "#1f77b4", "FALSE" = "#e41a1c")) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = grade_map,
    labels = names(grade_map),
    limits = c(min(grade_map), max(grade_map))
  ) +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(4, 12)) +
  scale_y_reverse(limits = c(10, 4.5), expand = expansion(mult = c(0.05, 0.3))) +
  labs(
    title = "How Ondra Stacks Up Against Other Elite Climbers",
    subtitle = "Among top climbers, he’s the only one leading in medals and outdoor difficulty.",
    x = "Hardest Outdoor Grade",
    y = "Average IFSC Ranking (Lower is Better)",
    size = "IFSC Medals",
    color = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "black"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
  )

ggsave("images/chart3.png", chart3, width = 9, height = 5)
Source: IFSC Medals + Public Grade Records | By Zoey Schultz
So how does Ondra compare to other top climbers?
This chart plots five elite climbers, comparing the hardest outdoor grade they’ve sent against their average IFSC competition rank. Bubble size represents the number of IFSC medals they’ve won.
Ondra is in a league of his own. He’s the only climber in this group to have sent a confirmed 9c — the hardest grade ever climbed — and still maintain a top-tier competition record. Others, like Jakob Schubert and Stefano Ghisolfi, have similar IFSC rankings and lots of medals, but their outdoor grades top out slightly lower.
Then there’s Tomoa Narasaki, a bouldering specialist, and Sean Bailey, an American climber with impressive medals but less outdoor pedigree. They both excel in specific areas, but don’t show the same all-around dominance.
This reinforces the idea that Ondra isn’t just good — he’s versatile, and he’s stayed relevant across a much wider set of challenges than most climbers ever attempt.

title: Why the Olympic Format Failed the World’s Best Climber
section: One Format, Three Disciplines — and It Cost Ondra a Medal
text:
One Format, Three Disciplines — and It Cost Ondra a Medal
Ondra, known primarily for his achievements in lead climbing and outdoor ascents, competed in the Tokyo 2020 Olympics under the combined format, which included speed climbing, bouldering, and lead. Final rankings were determined by multiplying each athlete’s placements across the three disciplines, meaning a lower placement in any one event could significantly affect the overall score.
Ondra placed 4th in speed, which was considered a strong result given that it is typically his weakest discipline. However, a 6th-place finish in bouldering, combined with 2nd in lead, resulted in a combined score that placed him 6th overall. While he performed well in both speed and lead, the bouldering round proved to be a limiting factor in his final ranking under the event’s scoring format.
This chart underscores the frustration many climbers felt with the 2020 format — a format that was split into separate events at Paris 2024.

title: Do Speed Climbers Peak Younger?
text:
Code
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  echo = TRUE,
  message = FALSE,
  warning = FALSE,
  results = 'hide'
)

suppressPackageStartupMessages({
  library(ggplot2)
  library(dplyr)
  library(readr)
  library(tidyr)
  library(janitor)
  library(scales)
  library(waffle)
  library(tibble)
})
Are speed climbers peaking younger than their bouldering or lead counterparts?
I am exploring whether speed climbers peak younger than bouldering or lead climbers to understand how age influences success across climbing disciplines. The physical and mental demands of each style may shape when athletes reach their prime, and that has big implications for training, team selection, and the future of the sport.
Code
ifsc <- read_csv("data/ifsc_finalists_full_with_ages.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

bubble_data <- ifsc |>
  count(discipline, age_at_competition, rank)

chart1 <- ggplot(bubble_data, aes(x = age_at_competition, y = rank, size = n, color = discipline)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 12)) +
  labs(
    title = "Speed Climbers Peak Earlier",
    subtitle = "Younger athletes are more common among top-ranked speed climbers.",
    x = "Age at Competition",
    y = "Final Rank (Lower is Better)",
    size = "Frequency",
    color = "Discipline",
    caption = "Source: IFSC Finalist Results (2010–2024) | Visualization by Zoey Schultz"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "black"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
  )

ggsave("images/chart1.png", chart1, width = 8, height = 5)
chart1
Speed climbing’s youth movement is hard to miss. This bubble chart reveals how younger athletes dominate the top ranks in speed, with the biggest bubbles clustering around ages 17 to 21. In contrast, top finishes in lead and bouldering are more spread out and tend to involve older competitors. The takeaway here is that speed rewards fast-twitch power and reaction time, traits that often peak earlier in life, while lead and bouldering may favor experience and endurance.
Code
podium <- ifsc |>
  filter(rank %in% 1:3) |>
  group_by(discipline) |>
  summarise(min_age = min(age_at_competition), max_age = max(age_at_competition), .groups = "drop")

chart2 <- ggplot(podium, aes(x = min_age, xend = max_age, y = discipline)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = max_age, yend = discipline), color = "#2b8cbe", size = 2) +
  geom_point(aes(x = min_age), color = "black", size = 4) +
  geom_point(aes(x = max_age), color = "black", size = 4) +
  labs(
    title = "Speed Podium Finishers Are Younger",
    subtitle = "1st–3rd place finishers in speed are younger than in other disciplines.",
    x = "Age at Competition",
    y = "Discipline",
    caption = "Source: IFSC Finalist Results (2010–2024) | Visualization by Zoey Schultz"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "black"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank()
  )

ggsave("images/chart2.png", chart2, width = 8, height = 5)
chart2
When it comes to the podium, speed climbers are not only younger, they’re consistently younger. This dumbbell chart compares the age ranges of 1st to 3rd place finishers across disciplines. Speed has the tightest spread and the youngest athletes at both ends. Lead and bouldering, by comparison, show wider age gaps and older champions. The chart reinforces the idea that climbing’s disciplines demand different skillsets and hit different athletic timelines.
Code
ages <- read_csv("data/ifsc_finalists_ages.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

ages_binned <- ages |>
  mutate(age_group = case_when(
    age < 18 ~ "<18",
    age < 21 ~ "18–20",
    age < 24 ~ "21–23",
    age < 27 ~ "24–26",
    TRUE ~ "27+"
  )) |>
  count(discipline, age_group) |>
  group_by(discipline) |>
  mutate(percent = round(n / sum(n) * 100)) |>
  ungroup()

waffle_data <- ages_binned |>
  filter(discipline == "Speed") |>
  select(age_group, percent) |>
  deframe()

chart3 <- waffle::waffle(
  parts = waffle_data,
  rows = 5,
  size = 0.75,
  colors = RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(5, "Blues"),
  title = "Half of Speed Finalists Are Under 21"
) +
  labs(
    subtitle = "Speed climbing shows a sharp concentration of teenage and early-20s competitors.",
    x = "Age Group Distribution",
    y = "Proportion of Finalists",
    caption = "Source: IFSC Finalist Age Data (2010–2024) | Visualization by Zoey Schultz"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 16, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, margin = margin(b = 8)),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 11, margin = margin(t = 10)),
    axis.text = element_blank(),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    legend.title = element_blank(),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 12)
  )

ggsave("images/chart3.png", chart3, width = 8, height = 5)
chart3
Most speed finalists aren’t just under 25, they are still in their teens or early 20s. This waffle chart shows that a striking percentage of speed climbers are under 21, with teens making up a huge chunk of the field. The same can’t be said for lead or bouldering, which skew older. In a sport where youth and agility matter, speed climbing is emerging as the discipline where teenagers can thrive — and often outpace their older peers.

title: Do Speed Climbers Peak Younger?
text:
Climbing Styles Age Differently
Speed climbers do appear to peak younger than their bouldering and lead peers. Their dominance at younger ages aligns with the sport’s emphasis on explosive power and quick-twitch ability, traits that often peak earlier in an athlete’s life. In contrast, lead and bouldering seem to favor athletes who have more experience, route-reading skills, and tactical endurance.
These trends aren’t just interesting — they shape athlete development pipelines, team selection strategies, and the future of competitive climbing.
